text: Let's now discuss the basic elements of the auction process.
Auctions Auctions are made up of three fundamental
elements, price, time and volume. Price advertises the opportunity, time regulates
each opportunity and volume measures the degree of success of each auction.
In order to understand any auction, it doesn't matter what the market might be,
you need to understand price, time and volume.
What this is telling us, in an auction, as price moves higher and lower,
it's an advertisement to anyone participating within the auction.
If there are high prices, various participants will participate.
If there are low prices, some participants will participate.
If there are fair prices, some participants will participate.
At each price there's a different advertisement for different participants.
In terms of the time, time measures and regulates each of these opportunities.
The more time it takes, the more participants have to engage at various opportunities.
Less time at a specific price represents a very advantageous opportunity, whereas
a longer time at a various price represents not as advantageous.
In terms of the volume, higher volume tends to tell us there's a lot of success of the
auction, whereas low volume tends to tell us there's less participation or less involvement
at those prices.
In terms of fair value, fair value is the price level that's attracting the greatest
volume of trades.
So fair value is where we spend most of our time trading.
Why?
Because fair value depicts or tells us the point in the market where buyers and sellers
If they are therefore in agreement, it's very very difficult to expect buyers to
buy up higher prices and sellers to sell lower prices and that is why we tend to
spend a lot of time around fair value. Identifying fair value is pivotal in
understanding forces within the market. The reason being is once we've
identified fair value, we then need to be cautious expecting a resumption of
the trend.
Markets can spend a long, long time trading around fair value before continuing in one
direction or another, and that is why it's pivot to understand when a market has found
fair value.
In terms of volume, volume determines whether or not divergences from value can be sustained.
Some days, buyers and sellers can be discouraged from moving away from fair value, and this
On other days, however, we can see price move very quickly away from value as it attracts
interest in the form of volume as the market starts to accept a new fair value or a new
value area.
This is important to understand, as it's telling us, when a market decides to move away from
fair value, the key factor to watch when a market is moving from fair value is the volume.
Higher volume tells us that the market is accepting moving away from that fair value,
whereas lower volume tells us the market is actually rejecting or not happy about
moving away from fair value, and more often than not, this tends to mean revert.
The objective of the market is to facilitate trade. That is why the
marketplace was created to facilitate trade.
Now the question you have to ask yourself, is it doing a good
or a bad job at facilitating trade at various prices?
And we can see that facilitation in
the volume. Higher volume suggests that we are doing a good job
whereas lower volume suggests we aren't.
